text: it's now a month since the taliban swept
to power in afghanistan seizing kabul
with barely a fight but a bit of rao has
broken out there between leaders of the
taliban over the makeup of the group's
new government senior taliban officials
have told the bbc the rom involved a
strong exchange of words at the
presidential palace over who should take
credit for the group's victory it's
believed the co-founder mulla abdulgani
barada wants the emphasis placed on the
diplomacy carried out by people like him
however khalil rahman
the minister for refugees believes
credit should be given to those who led
the fighting the taliban have denied
these reports but we've got more details
from you for you from our correspondent
yugita lemai
now coming to the fore this uh this war
of words between uh mullah brother and
khalil haqqani mullah brother as we know
is leading taliban negotiations in doha
he is the deputy prime minister in this
new government that was announced last
tuesday by the taliban
and he believes that it's the political
side of the taliban the people who led
the negotiations that they should be the
people given the credit for the taliban
being able to control afghanistan now
and therefore should have more power in
the government khalil haqqani is from
the haqqani network it is
a part of the taliban but it's also an
organization that is considered a
terrorist organization by the us
it you know there are other leaders in
the taliban who have been responsible uh
for military actions taken by the
taliban in afghanistan and they believe
that it's actually the military
onslaught
that they launched again afghan
government forces that has led to a
situation today where the taliban
control uh all of afghanistan and and
that certainly seems to be what the
fight is about uh we've also been told
by taliban sources bbc pashto has been
told by taliban sources that there was
actually a brawl that broke out between
the followers of these two leaders and
uh it's just been over a week since this
new government was announced and uh you
know a serious war of words between two
top leaders
is a you know raises serious questions
about what kind of stability one can
expect under this new taliban regime
we've had the
the president of the international
committee for the red cross who's in
afghanistan who's saying he's seen a lot
of suffering
a lot of poverty over uh his many
decades of
working but he's never seen a situation
as he is right now in afghanistan we
know there was a u.n uh un fundraising
conference earlier this week and
billions of funds uh billions of dollars
in aid have been raised
a lot of the international funds that
were going into afghanistan have been
frozen by many individual donors as well
as international financial organizations
fearing that they will fall into taliban
hands fearing that they will be misused
but what we've been hearing now
repeatedly from un leaders from uh
from top top officials in other agencies
is that
uh somehow the global community needs to
find a way to make sure that those funds
reach the ordinary people of afghanistan
because uh you know it's those people
who were suffering there's people we've
seen thousands of people who've been
displaced because of the fighting even
when they've gone back to their homes
now because there's relative peace in
the country uh they're going back to
destroyed homes they're going back
to places where they don't have jobs
anymore 18 million people the un says in
urgent need of support
